net.sf.mmm.util.date.api

Enum DateUnit

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<DateUnit>
      • net.sf.mmm.util.date.api.DateUnit
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<DateUnit>, AttributeReadValue<String>, Datatype, SimpleDatatype<String>

    public enum DateUnit
extends Enum<DateUnit>
implements SimpleDatatype<String>
    The enum contains the units of a date. These are DAY, WEEK, MONTH, and YEAR.
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Joerg Hohwiller (hohwille at users.sourceforge.net)
    See Also:
    TimeUnit

    • Enum Constant Summary

      Enum Constants 
      Enum Constant and Description
      DAY
      The day of the month starting with 1.
      MONTH
      The month of the year starting with 1 (NOT 0 like Calendar does).
      WEEK
      The week (of the year) starting with 1.
      YEAR
      The year.

      • getValue

        public String getValue()

        Specified by:

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns the official String representation of this Datatype. While the general contract of Object.toString() is very weak and mainly used for debugging, the contract here is very strong. The returned String has to be suitable for end-users and official output to any kind of sink.
        ATTENTION:
        This method is not supposed to do internationalization (I18N). See NlsMessage for this purpose and implement NlsObject if you want to support I18N/L10N.
        Specified by:
        toString in interface Datatype
        Overrides:
        toString in class Enum<DateUnit>
        Returns:
        the official String representation to display the value of this Datatype.

      • getCalendarField

        public int getCalendarField(Calendar calendar)
        This method delegates to Calendar.get(int). However, it will return the month in a natural way from 1 to 12. Java Calendar returns 0 for January instead of 1 and so forth what is the cause of many mistakes.
        Parameters:
        calendar - is the Calendar.
        Returns:
        the requested calendar field for this DateUnit.

      • setCalendarField

        public void setCalendarField(Calendar calendar,
                             int unitValue)
        This method delegates to Calendar.set(int, int). However, it will treat the month in a natural way from 1 to 12. Java Calendar expects 0 for January instead of 1 and so forth what is the cause of many mistakes.
        Parameters:
        calendar - is the Calendar.
        unitValue - is the value to set.

      • getCalendarId

        public int getCalendarId()
        This method gets the ID constant for Calendar operations such as Calendar.get(int).
        Returns:
        the calendar ID.

      • fromValue

        public static DateUnit fromValue(String value)
        This method gets the DateUnit for the given value.
        Parameters:
        value - is the value of the requested DateUnit.
        Returns:
        the requested DateUnit or null if no such DateUnit exists.
